data.text: INDEX
Appendix A - Acute Pain Analgesia Stepladder For Neonates 28 weeks gestation to 28 days of age
Appendix B - Pain Assessment Tools
Appendix C – Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose
To clarify the choice of analgesic and dose used in babies cared for on the Neonatal Unit.
To ensure that all neonates receive adequate analgesia if required.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals
(Refer to Appendix C)
3. 0 Measurement of Neonatal Pain
Neonates should be assessed for pain routinely before and after procedures and on the post natal/labour ward following difficult deliveries.
NIPS (Neonatal Infant Pain Scale) should be used to assess the level of pain that is being experienced. (Refer to Appendix B)
Using the pain stepladder adequate pain relief should be identified and administered. (Refer to Appendix A)
Sucrose

Therapeutic Indications - a mild analgesic which can be used prior to routine procedures. It is only effective when given orally. This is an unlicensed product; parents must be informed prior to use and appropriate records kept in accordance with the Trust policy on the use of unlicensed medicines.
Procedures for which sucrose is a suitable analgesia
Blood taking by heel pricks, venepuncture or arterial stabs;
Intravenous catheter insertion;
Lumbar puncture;
Suture removal;
Urinary catheter;
Intramuscular and subcutaneous injections.
Formulation - Sucrose solution 24%.
Dosage of sucrose solution 24%
Administration
Following consent from parents, give a dose of sucrose orally, mainly to the anterior part of the tongue, 2 minutes before the procedure;
The analgesic effect is improved if the baby is able to suck a dummy moistened with sucrose at the same time;
Sucrose should be used in conjunction with environmental and behavioural measures to relieve pain (e.g. positioning, swaddling, and containment);
It is ineffective if given by nasogastric or orogastric tube.
Storage - store at room temperature in a locked medicine cupboard. Preparation is presented in single patient vials and should be discarded immediately after use.
Contraindications:
Infants not established on enteral feeds;
Hereditary fructose intolerance;
Infants whose mothers are taking methadone;
Infants of > 2 months corrected gestational age.
Lidocaine (Lignocaine)
Therapeutic Indication - Lidocaine (Lignocaine) is used as a local anaesthetic prior to invasive procedures e.g. insertion chest drain.
Formulation - Injection 0.5% (5mg in 1ml) and Injection 1% (10mg in 1ml).

Dosage and administration of lidocaine - up to 3mg/kg as subcutaneous injection using a fine gauge needle (27-29 gauge), repeated no more than every 4 hours. Monitor for signs of toxicity for 30 minutes after injection.
Contraindications - avoid inflamed or infected tissue and intravascular injection. Observe injection areas for tissue trauma.
Paracetamol

Therapeutic indications - used for mild to moderate pain relief, this is an unlicensed use for patients in this age group, for this reason parents/guardian must be informed and appropriate records kept according to the trusts policy on the use of unlicensed medicines.
Formulation - oral suspension 120mg in 5ml, intravenous infusion 10mg/ml, suppositories 60mg.
Dosage and administration:
Oral paracetamol:
Intravenous (IV) paracetamol:
Rectal paracetamol:
Contraindications - use in caution in renal or liver impairment.
Morphine
Therapeutic Indications - opioid analgesic used for the treatment of severe pain, premedication prior to intubation and as sedation in ventilated infants in intensive care.
Formulation - injection 10mg in 1ml for maintenance intravenous (IV) infusion and 1mg/ml for slow bolus loading dose.
Dosage and administration of morphine - dilute in glucose 5%, glucose 10% or sodium chloride 0.9% for continuous intravenous infusion:
Slow bolus loading dose: 50-100microgram/kg, followed by:
Continuous infusion dose: 5-20microgram/kg/hour; Maximum dose 40microgram/kg/hour;
Adverse effects - respiratory depression, hypotension, vomiting, constipation.
Staffing and Training
All medical staff involved in the prescription of analgesia for neonates will have this protocol as part of their induction.
The current edition of the British National Formulary for Children (BNFC) will be available on the clinical ward areas.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued to all staff to highlight key changes in clinical practice to include a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly. Midwives that are on maternity leave or ‘bank' staff have letters sent to their home address to update them on current clinical changes.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's staff newsletter that is sent via email to all staff.
References
BNF for Children, online edition – accessed 30/10/19

East of England ODN (2018) Sucrose guideline (Online) Available at: https://www.networks.nhs.uk/nhs-networks/eoe-neonatal-odn/guidelines/current- guidelines/sucrose-guideline/at_download/file (accessed on 12/11/2019).
Rosie Hospital, Neonatal Unit Handbook, 2019

Sucrose for analgesia in newborn infants undergoing painful procedures (2013) Stevens B, Yamada J, Lee GY Ohlsson A, Cochrane database of systematic reviews 2013, issue  Art No: CD001069. DOI: 10.1002/14651858. CD001069 pub 4
‘The development of a tool to assess neonatal pain; Lawrence J, Alcock D, McGrath P, Kay J, Brook Macmurray S, and Dulberg C, Neonatal Network 12 (6) pp59-66.

Pain Assessment Tools Neonatal/Infant Pain Scale (NIPS)
A score greater than 3 indicates pain

table_items.text: Restful face, neutral expression Tight facial muscles, furrowed brow, jaw, chin (negative facial expression – nose, mouth and brow)
Cry 0 - No cry 1 – Whimper 2 – Vigorous cry
Quiet, not crying Mild moaning, intermittent. Loud scream, rising, shrill continuous (note, silent cry may be scored if baby is intubated as evidenced by obvious mouth and facial movements).
Breathing Patterns 0 – Relaxed 1 – Change in breathing
Usual pattern for this infant In drawing, irregular, faster than usual, gagging and breath holding.
No muscular rigidity, occasional random movements of arms. Tense straight legs, rigid and/or rapid extension, flexion.
No muscular rigidity, occasional random movements of arms. Tense straight legs, rigid and/or rapid extension, flexion.
Quiet, peaceful sleeping or alert random leg movement. Alert, restless and thrashing
